FacilityName: Arvah B. Hopkins Electric Generating Station

_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Compressor, Evaporator, Control Valves, Ammonia Receiver, Aqua Ammonia Storage Tank, Aqua Forwarding Skid
_prev_prog_3.Description: Hopkins Power Plant uses a web-based PSM/RMP program management tool that contains all information developed under the 1910.119 Process Safety Management Standard and the EPA 40 CFR Part 68 Risk Management Program available to their chilled water system and aqua injection system operators and managers.  Volume 2 of their program describes in detail the responsibilities each manager has for implementing each element of the PSM/RMP program; and, the responsibility each operator has for integrating the PSM/RMP Program into the way they manage the ammonia process.  Program requirements, program responsibilities, a training Management system and compliance documentation are also found on the website.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1. ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY POLICIES

Hopkins Power Plant recognizes management's responsibility in protecting its employees, equipment, property, and the environment.  The safety and health of all personnel are very important.  The control of accidents has been and will continue to be a basic responsibility of all personnel in the facility.



The Hopkins Power Plant PSM/RMP program assigns and documents the specific responsibilities for developing, implementing, and integrating the OSHA PSM and the EPA RMP standards into its safety program.  The Hopkins Power Plant PSM/RMP program focuses attention on "Making PSM/RMP the way we manage our ammonia based processing operations" rather than a project we expect to complete and put on the shelf when the filing date has passed.



Hopkins Power Plant believes that employee participation is the key to a successful program.  Operating level employees, particularly the Ammonia System and the Aqua Ammonia System Operators, have been deeply involved in the development and implementation of the PSM/RMP Program and they assume the major responsibility for operating safely.



2.  STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED

Hopkins Power Plant produces power from Natural Gas and #2 Fuel Oil operates two separate ammonia processes.  (1) An enclosed Ammonia Refrigeration System to chill water for cooling combustion turbine inlet air, and (2) A system for injecting Aqua Ammonia into stack gas to reduce the NOx products being released into atmosphere.



3.  SUMMARY OF WORST CASE AND ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIOS

Section 68.25 of the RMP Regulation defines a worst-case scenario as a release of the largest quantity of a regulated substance from a vessel or process line failure that results in the greatest distance to a specified endpoint of 200 ppm (ERPG-2). 



Please refer to onsite documentation for Off-Site Consequence/Hazard Assessment data.



4.  DESCRIPTION OF THE HOPKINS POWER PLANT ACCIDENTAL REL

EASE PREVENTION PROGRAM

Hopkins Power Plant conducts triennial PSM/RMP audits of the entire program to identify strengths and weaknesses and make improvements.  Hopkins Power Plant considers the PSM/RMP manuals to be living documents that must be updated and revised regularly to maintain their viability.



Hopkins Power Plant emphasizes and insists on employee participation from the Chilled Water System and the Aqua Ammonia System operators in all aspects of the development, implementation, and integration of their PSM/RMP Program.



Hopkins Power Plant provides comprehensive training in Safe Work Practices, Ammonia and Aqua Ammonia Properties, Standard Operating Procedures, Emergency Response, Aqua system and Chiller System Processes, and  PSM/RMP Principles.





5.  FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT RELEASE HISTORY

The Aqua Injection System and the Chilled Water Systems are both new so there have been no releases of ammonia or aqua ammonia that have resulted in an injury, or that had an off-site impact, or that resulted in significant property damage either on-sit or off-site.



6.  EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

Hopkins Power Plant emergency response policies have been designed to comply with all applicable state and federal Regulations.  These policies summarize the actions to be taken in response to a chemical spill.  In the event of a spill, the Hopkins Power Plant Emergency Response Team will react with the proper actions, as listed in the Emergency Response Plan, in association with the local fire department



7.  PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Hopkins Power Plant the PSM/RMP program as a set of living documents and procedures that will require constant attention, development, and revision.



Hopkins Power Plant expects to improve safety performance by emphasizing the following elements of their PSM/RMP program:



(1)  Employee Participation is the Key to a successful program.  Both the managers and system operators are deeply involved in identifying the P&IDs, d

eveloping and updating the Standard Operating Procedures, and performing the documented Preventative Maintenance Inspections.



(2)  The Hopkins Power Plant PSM/RMP program is (a) computer based, (b) user friendly, (c) written to minimize paperwork and maximize documentation, and (d) written to be understood and used by the operating level employees.



(3)  All recommendations developed during the Process Hazards Analysis and most recent audit were designed to improve the safety performance of the Hopkins Power Plant Ammonia Refrigeration and Aqua Ammonia Injection Systems.  Hopkins Power Plant expects to evaluate each recommendation in a timely manner and implement, as soon a possible, those recommendations that will reduce the possibility of release and/or mitigate the consequences of an unintentional release.
